name: Rainbow Elders Calgary
title: Rainbow Elders Calgary
main_text: Calgary Pride Parade, August 31, 2025 Rainbow Elders Calgary members Nia and Tina were proud Pride Parade marshals this year! Rainbow Elders Calgary is a volunteer-run, non-profit organization determined to make a significant difference in the lives of 2SLGBTQ+ seniors. We know that social isolation and loneliness are major issues for aging members of our gay community. Therefore, we work to provide support and friendship by organizing safe social events such as: picnics in the park; coffee socials; evenings out and monthly meetups where folk can chat, be themselves and feel safe. Visit our About Us page for more details and information! _ rainbowelderscalgary@gmail.com Mailing address: Rainbow Elders Calgary, c/o Centre for Sexuality Suite 700 - 1509 Centre Street S Calgary Alberta T2G 2E6 Don't miss anything! Follow us on Instagram for the latest news and events. Stay in the loop! Join our email list! Send an email to rainbowelderscalgary@gmail.com with "Subscribe me" in the subject line. rainbowelderscalgary@gmail.com Many thanks to the wonderful folks at Great West News who published our ad in every one of their community newsletters - for FREE! In the spirit of respect, truth and reconciliation, Rainbow Elders Calgary would like to acknowledge that we live, work and play on the traditional territories of the people of the Treaty 7 region in Southern Alberta, which includes the Blackfoot Confederacy (comprising the Siksika, Piikani, and Kainai First Nations), the Tsuut‚Äôina First Nation, and the Stoney Nakoda (including the Chiniki, Bearspaw, and Wesley First Nations). This land is also home to M√©tis Nation of Alberta, Region III. Click here for Treaty 7 information. name: Social Sector Social Club
title: Home | Social Sector Social
main_text: SOCIAL SECTOR SOCIAL CLUB Welcome! Social Sector Social Club aims to bring non-profit professionals together to share ideas, seek support and celebrate each other. We create spaces for connection, collaboration, professional growth and fun. In a world where non-profit work can often feel isolating and overwhelming, we believe in the power of community to uplift, inspire, and sustain the individuals and teams behind the mission. ‚Äã ‚ÄãThe Social Sector Social Club is based in Calgary, Alberta. Gather Our gatherings bring non-profit professionals together in a casual, welcoming space where ideas spark, collaborations form, and support networks grow. Work in the non-profit/social impact sector is hard, stressful and daunting. It can often feel pretty lonely. These informal meet-ups remind us that we‚Äôre not in this work alone. Lead Leadership in the non-profit sector isn‚Äôt just about titles - it‚Äôs about action, influence, and the ability to inspire others. Our leadership lunches and development opportunities create space for emerging and established leaders to exchange ideas, navigate challenges, and grow together. Play Rest and joy are just as essential as hard work - but they're easily and often forgotten in our line of work. Our group activities offer a way to unwind, rediscover old and explore new hobbies, and bring more fun and friendship into your life. Because when we take care of ourselves and each other, we create a stronger, more sustainable sector. Learn The non-profit world is constantly evolving, and staying ahead requires knowledge, insight, and fresh perspectives. Through thought leadership, actionable advice, and shared resources, we help non-profit professionals uncover new ways to activate their communities, drive change, and hopefully, improve their wellbeing. Sign up Sign up to connect

title: Recess Calgary | Take A Break
main_text: Our Community our community ‚Äã Our school of thought: Recess Calgary values community. Our community is brought together by adults who simply want to have more play in their week. Play happens by having a bunch of people willing to embrace their inner child, be open to new friendships and get exercise (with a bit of competitive spirit). Our only ask to participate is an inclusive, open attitude that is welcoming to all types of people, athletic ability and care for how you show up to have fun. If you‚Äôre looking for an untraditional, semi structured way to meet people, exercise and just be a kid, Recess Calgary is the place. Come out once, twice a month or every week and be a part of our community. Hi! I'm Tyson, founder of the community Recess Calgary! I'm just another Calgarian with an idea to bring people together. Think of me as your gym coach (but nicer), a fan of sport and exercise. I look forward to seeing you at the next session! > Coach T. Grab your friends and play those old school gym games that you didn't know you missed. ‚Äã A recess Class We have Group Wellness Opportunities! name: Hope WWC
title: Calgary Chapter | HOPE worldwide Canada
main_text: Calgary Chapter About Our Chapter Our Calgary chapter is made up of a diverse group of volunteers from all over Canada and we are looking to provide a variety of services throughout Calgary! Some of the programs we focus on include community clean-ups, fundraisers to serve at the centers of HOPE worldwide Philippines, supporting Calgary‚Äôs food bank in their mission to fight hunger, and bringing hope to people in hospitals or away from their families during special holidays, such as Christmas. Our Fundraising will help support these programs and as we grow our chapter we will expand our services to other programs throughout Calgary and HOPE Centers around the world. Come volunteer with us! Donate to our Chapter Volunteer Opportunities HOPE IN ACTION June 21st, 2025 Join us for our annual fundraiser! HOPE worldwide Canada - Calgary Chapter, please contact Jimmy Taing at jimmy.taing@hopewwcanada.org. REGISTER/DONATE HERE Ongoing Programs Recent News Bringing hope and changing the lives of Calgarians Volunteers from Calgary seek to feed, clothe, care and welcome those who are in need in their community. Read More Jimmy Taing Calgary Chapter Director Contact Jimmy Taing is the Calgary Chapter Director for HOPE worldwide Canada. He immigrated to Calgary when he was nine. Jimmy has lived there since, and loves this place he now calls home. He volunteers because he wants to help the less fortunate in the city of Calgary and globally. Jimmy truly believes that everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and love. He is currently working as a math teacher and loves to go travelling with his wife, Pamela. Jimmy‚Äôs hobbies are playing sports, hiking, biking, and listening to people‚Äôs stories. Email: jimmy.taing@hopewwcanada.org

main_text: Equity in Action, Dignity for All Working together with ethnocultural and equity-seeking groups to advance equity through transformational change in communities. Equity in Action, Dignity for All Working together with ethnocultural and equity-seeking groups to advance equity through transformational change in communities. It‚Äôs a long journey to create a more just and equitable world. It takes courage, persistence, and, most importantly, it takes all of us. We need more voices joining together, more supporters stepping up, and more communities building their power, side by side. That‚Äôs why we focus on engagement that is meaningful, where everyone feels heard, valued, and is part of the change. We all have a role to play. We can all demonstrate our support, the value, and the respect we have for each other. Together, we can turn our collective action into lasting and transformational systems change. title: Home - Calgary Data For Good
main_text: Empowering Communities Through Data RSVP To Our Next Meetup Volunteer with Us Meetup RSVP Data Support for Organizations Calgary Chapter Resources Site The Calgary Data for Good Chapter Data For Good is a collective of volunteer do-gooders, who want to use their powers for good to help make our communities better through data. We help nonprofit and social organizations harness the power of their data through analytics and visualizations in order to leverage their impact in the community. The team in Calgary is led by Geoff Zakaib and other volunteers who are committed to making an impact through data in Calgary. RSVP To Our Next Meetup How we can help Data for Good in Calgary works with organizations in the nonprofit / social sector in a couple of ways: DataThons are weekend events that involve a large number of volunteers focusing on analytics & visualizations with organizations that have a lot of data and are relatively advanced in their data practices. DataCorps is a program of smaller scale projects of variable length where a group of Data Ambassadors will work with organizations that need help with data fundamentals at any stage of the Data Lifecycle. Meetup presentations are held every month where speakers from various industries present on topics related to data analytics & non-profits. Community Community is at the heart of Data for Good, whether through in the people who create and manage not-for-profit and non-governmental organizations, in supporting the people that such organizations serve, or in our own team who simply want to do some good. Data for Good Calgary is happy to share the knowledge throughout the community and host speaking events to discuss the value of data. Want to speak at our event? Data Work You don‚Äôt need degrees or certifications to start working with data! With some patience and open-mindedness, anyone can pick up the tools to start collecting and dissecting the multitudes of different data that are so essential to day-to-day operat...

name: Calgary Women's Literary Club
title: Calgary Women's Literary Club | A Book Club with a Difference
main_text: Courtesy of Wikimedia Commons Ernest Hemingway famously claimed, ‚ÄúAll modern American literature comes from one book by Mark Twain called Huckleberry Finn . [‚Ä¶] There was nothing before. There has been nothing as good since.‚Äù How can such high praise be reconciled when The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is both one of the most beloved and one of the most controversial novels in American history? On Tuesday, November 18, Janet H. delivered a well-researched and passionate presentation on Mark Twain. Janet examined the man, the writer, and Huckleberry Finn‚Äôs lasting place in modern literature. Twain‚Äôs writings address the horrors and injustices of slavery, and Janet handled this sensitive subject with care and insight. After showing Conan O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs heartfelt acceptance speech for the Mark Twain award for American Humor, Janet admitted she knew little about the writer before her research‚Äîother than knowing he was funny. She learned numerous autobiographies exist (‚Äúshouldn‚Äôt there be only one?‚Äù) and recommended The Autobiography of Mark Twain (1959), edited by Charles Neider. Mark Twain was born Samuel Langhorne Clemens in 1835 and spent his childhood along the Mississippi River in Hannibal, Missouri. Twain was adventurous, humorous, and empathetic by nature. Upon his father‚Äôs death, Twain lived a ‚ÄúCharles Dickens-type misery‚Äù as a printer‚Äôs apprentice. He later became a journeyman printer, a steamboat pilot, a Confederate soldier, and a newspaper reporter. Writing about fraud and corruption was dangerous, so he began using the pen name ‚ÄúMark Twain‚Äù (a nautical term). His extensive travels through Europe, the Middle East, and Hawaii inspired his humorous and satirical travel writings. Twain married and had four children‚Äîonly one living passed the age of thirty. While living in Hartford, Connecticut, Twain wrote many of his classics: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876), The Prince and the Pauper (1881 ), Life on the Mississippi (1883), and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn ...

title: Bell‚Äôs Bookstore Cafe - 1515A 34 Ave SW, Calgary - Full Menu and Reviews
main_text: Menu Oops! Our menu is under update. Sorry for the inconvenience. About Coffee & Tea, Bookstores Price Range : $11-30 ($$) star Yelp rating 3.5 stars Location Adress: 1515A 34 Ave SW, Calgary, AB T2T 2B1 Phone: (403) 243-3095 Work Hours Mon 7:00 am - 6:00 pm Tue 7:00 am - 6:00 pm Wed 7:00 am - 6:00 pm Thu 7:00 am - 6:00 pm Fri 7:00 am - 6:00 pm Sat 8:00 am - 5:00 pm Sun 8:00 am - 5:00 pm Business info move_to_inbox Take-out Yes local_parking Parking Street, Private Lot directions_bike Bike Parking Yes transit_enterexit Outdoor Seating Yes wifi Wi-Fi Free Reviews Lisa C. star star star star star 22 December 2025 It's Sunday morning. The sun is shining. Nothing on the agenda this morning other than a nice sleep in. Annnnd then, my dogs start barking. And barking. And barking. And even some time in the back yard won't quiet them. Fine, we're off for a walk!! Luckily for my dogs (and my husband!), my morning grouch was calmed when we came across Bell's Bookstore Cafe, a delightful little coffee shop / bookstore only blocks away from our house. We were greeted by rows of books, a few little trinkets for sale and the smell of fresh baking. This place has it all. Friendly staff, great coffee and a surprisingly large selection of homemade treats (including gluten-free options!). Who can be unhappy any longer?! They also have a water dish and place to tie up your puppies just outside the door. These guys are even true to their posted operating hours - we arrived just after 8 and they were already open. Not always true with small businesses and early mornings. The surroundings are not super posh, but it is comfortable and you can tell it is loved by its owners and customers alike. I get the feeling that Bell's is fiercely supported by the local community, and I think that is great. Sure, the Starbucks and Phil & Sebastian's down the road have figured out how to perfect the same americano time after time. But this place feels like home, they make a damn good coffee and delicio...

name: More Neighbours Calgary
title: More Neighbours Calgary
main_text: More homes, more opportunity. More Neighbours Calgary is changing the conversation on housing. Join the Discord Get the Newsletter Howdy Neighbour! Defenders of the status quo dominate public discourse on housing. More Neighbours Calgary is committed to making Calgary a 21st century city. We provide a strong voice in support of sustainable housing growth. Calgary has a long history of affordability with seemingly limitless supply. Now, our housing advantage is disappearing, as prices rise and supply shrinks. Car-centric neighbourhoods and a sprawling footprint are adding to the social, economic and climate impacts. We need all types of homes, for all shapes and sizes of families , in all parts of the city. The housing crises of Toronto and Vancouver are on our doorstep. It‚Äôs time we stop limiting much-needed housing. Housing is a basic need and every Calgarian should have a safe place to call home. Let's work together to create and enforce strong policies to address the housing challenges we face now and in the future. We commit to bringing pro-housing voices to the forefront of public discourse. We can challenge the status quo and find real solutions to our housing crisis by: advocating for zoning reform legalizing a broader range of housing types mobilizing volunteer energy and working across political divides Get in touch. For media or volunteer inquiries contact us at info@moreneighbourscalgary.ca

name: End of the Rainbow Foundation
title: End of the Rainbow Foundation ‚Äì Helping LGBTQ+ People to be Successful in Canada
main_text: End of the Rainbow Foundation The End of the Rainbow Foundation creates sponsorship circles (groups of five), hosts support groups, and provides education to help LGBTQ+ people settle in their homes and community. Our foundation hosts the Calgary LGBTQ+ Refugee Centre and the Calgary LGBTQ+ Private Sponsorship Program settling SOGIESC refugees from outside Canada. The foundation hosts a variety of volunteer run support groups and mentor services. We are dedicated to all people of any sexual orientation and gender identity (LGBTQ+ or SOGIESC 1 ), whether they are longtime citizens, or new Canadian refugees, or immigrants. Help Sponsor an LGBTQ+ Refugee with your donation! The End of the Rainbow Foundation is a Private Foundation with Charitable Registration Number: 74824 1882 RR0001. Donate to the End of the Rainbow Foundation Note 1. We use LGBTQ+ and Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity & Expression and Sexual Characteristics (SOGIESC) interchangeably. All people have a sexual orientation and gender identity. When we use either term we include lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, two-spirit, queer, questioning, and plus+ as indicating: intersex, asexual, demisexual, pansexual, omnisexual, gender-neutral, genderqueer, pangender, men who have sex with men (MSM), women who have sex with women (WSW), and all the other sexual diversities that we are missing. For a comprehensive list of definitions, we suggest the following link: https://egale.ca/awareness/glossary-of-terms/

name: Street Cats YYC
title: HOME | Street Cats YYC
main_text: NIGHT OUTREACH Community Street Level Engagement GET INVOLVED HARM REDUX It is our intent to treat our community with the compassion & understanding we have needed ourselves, to come from an evidence-based public health perspective, to prioritize social justice, to do our best to be good to each other, and to be vocal about social misconceptions and hatred. We intend to speak up about injustice and keep our boots on the ground for direct action. We believe in and advocate for the rights, dignity, and autonomy of PWUD, sex workers, and street-involved folks. They are our community; WE are current, former, and/or the friends and family of PWUD, sex workers, and street-involved folks. ‚ÄúWhen we talk about harm reduction, we often reduce it to a public health framework, [one of] reducing risk. That‚Äôs harm reduction with a small ‚Äòh-r‚Äô. Harm reduction is meeting people where they are but not leaving them there. But Harm Reduction with a capital ‚ÄòH‚Äô and ‚ÄòR‚Äô‚Äîthis is the movement, one that shifts resources and power to the people who are most vulnerable to structural violence. This includes: building community for and empowering directly impacted people, or ‚Äúpeople who are not seen;‚Äù disruption; changing narratives; solidarity; and fighting for social justice." -Monique Tula WISH LIST Help secure some much needed items that we run out of often or are asked for frequently CONTRIBUTE TO COMMUNITY CARE SEE MORE

name: Sparrow Art Space
title: SPARROW ARTSPACE |  Creativity  Collaboration  Community
main_text: CREATIVITY COMMUNITY COLLABORATION Call to Artists for Residencies - all art forms! Call for Treasurer for Sparrow Arts Society Board of Directors Join our creative, dynamic team! Would you like to make a difference in Calgary's arts community through strong financial leadership? Join Sparrow Arts Society as our Treasurer. Learn More Wasakamapiwak Collective presents Vessels Dec 4 to Jan 30, open to the public Thurs-Sat 11am-6pm Vessels is a group residency and art exhibition featuring twelve local Indigenous artists: Danielle Piper, Jasmine Piper, Chris Piper, Riel Starr, Matt Hiltermann, Amber Boyd, Jamie Rozema-Stinson, Hilary McDonnell, Brendan McDonnell, Patricia Grimwood, Pih√™siw Grimwood, and Sarah Whalen-Lunn . They will be exploring the theme of vessels in its many forms and meanings. From baskets and pots to shoes, bags, garments, drums, and animal hides, the artists interpret the vessel as both a physical container and a symbolic space for story, identity, and tradition. The exhibition invites visitors to experience how vessels hold not only materials but also memory, culture, and connection. Through diverse mediums and practices, the participating artists reflect on the ways vessels carry histories, sustain communities, and embody the living relationship between people and the land. The residency will conclude at the end of January with a closing gathering and group discussion, offering an opportunity to hear directly from the artists about their creative processes, experiences, and the stories behind their work. Vessels celebrates the continuity of Indigenous artistry and the many forms through which culture is carried forward. Upcoming events. Follow our journey. name: Alberta Women‚Äôs Science Network
title: Welcome to AWSN | awsn
main_text: Welcome to AWSN AWSN‚Äôs primary focus is to connect, unite, support and promote Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) programs throughout the province. As a network, AWSN creates a collaborative environment where member groups and volunteers help each other, learning from each others‚Äô experiences, successes and challenges. Along with our long-term volunteers, we have been fortunate this year to gain many new creative minds, who are lending their time and expertise across the board and our various committees. AWSN activities focus on supporting host programs through funding, in-kind support and volunteer resource connections. We categorized these activities under three core pillars: Recruitment, Retention and Recognition. Latest Updates WinSTEM Week, organized by AWSN (Alberta Women‚Äôs Science Network), is an annual, province-wide initiative dedicated to increasing the visibility, recognition, and engagement of women in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) across Alberta. Held around Ada Lovelace Day, WinSTEM Week celebrates achievement, fosters mentorship, and empowers the next generation of STEM leaders. One of the key highlights of the week is the Athena and Minerva Awards, which honour the outstanding contributions of women in STEM at various career stages. Through a wide range of community-driven events, including STEM outreach activities, panel discussions, workshops, and networking opportunities. WinSTEM Week amplifies the voices of women and promotes inclusivity and accessibility in STEM fields. WinSTEM Week is now officially recognized in perpetuity by the Government of Alberta. WinSTEM Week is here to stay! WinSTEM Week 2025 - October 12-18, 2025

name: Calgary Mountain Bike Alliance
title: Calgary Mountain Bike Alliance | Ride It Like You Built It!
main_text: Building trails for the people! For over 25 years, the Calgary Mountain Bike Alliance (CMBA) has been building and maintaining sustainable singletrack trails in Calgary and Kananaskis. We are committed to creating safe, world-class trails and skills parks. We strive to grow a passionate and involved mountain bike community. Donate Join Volunteer Trail Organization Social Jul 24, 2025 Join us at Calgary Cycle Southwood on Saturday, July 26 from 9 AM to 5 PM for their Trail Organization Social (they‚Äôre opening early just for members). Founded in 1996 to represent the growing community of mountain-bikers, the CMBA has been part of Calgary‚Äôs mountain biking scene for nearly 30 years. Always volunteer-driven, the focus has gradually evolved and shifted based on the needs of the time, volunteers‚Äô interests and the opportunities and relationships that have been developed. Initial efforts were successful in securing the right of mountain bikers to use the informal and formal trails in Bowmont Park and Nose Hill, when a ban had been threatened. In the late 90‚Äôs and early 00‚Äôs, the focus shifted to trail maintenance and efforts to get a bike skills park built somewhere in Calgary. In time, as the CMBA‚Äôs relationships with the City and Province grew stronger, the focus moved away from advocacy toward trail-building and trail maintenance, working in collaboration with the land managers. Numerous trails were built or improved in areas across the city. The Ridgeback trail in Kananaskis was constructed by the CMBA in 2009-10 and upgraded in 2015. In 2016, the CMBA was finally successful in building Calgary‚Äôs first public mountain bike skills park in Fish Creek Provincial Park. On the heels of the new Alberta Trails Act (2022), a new trail development project was initiated in the Jumpingpound Creek area of Kananaskis and construction began in 2024. name: Indigenous Gathering Place Society of Calgary
title: Indigenous Gathering Place Society of Calgary
main_text: Welcome to the future home of the Indigenous Gathering Place in Calgary For Indigenous Peoples. By Indigenous Peoples. Our Vision We share, connect, heal, renew and celebrate Indigenous cultures The Indigenous Gathering Place is a space we‚Äôre creating together that will be a much-needed central gathering place for Indigenous Peoples‚Äô spiritual, emotional, cultural, and social well-being in Calgary. It will be a space where we share, connect, heal, renew and celebrate Indigenous cultures. A place to protect Indigenous practices, languages, Elders‚Äô wisdom and oral and written teachings among all nations and all our relations. We envision a place that is inclusive to all Indigenous and non-Indigenous peoples, accessible and centrally located with indoor and outdoor ceremony space that is culturally and historically significant, close to the river. A Space of Healing ‚ÄúAn Indigenous Gathering Place will be a space of healing. Those who have been disconnected from our culture and teachings will have a chance to find their way home through Ceremony.‚Äù ‚ÄîThe Elders Knowledge Circle, Treaty 7 Territory DID YOU KNOW THAT CURRENTLY THERE ARE‚Ä¶ 500+ Cultural and spiritual places in Calgary 0 Cultural and spiritual places in Calgary for Indigenous people Why the Indigenous Gathering Place is needed Indigenous Peoples have gathered to celebrate, learn, share, practice and heal for centuries. Calgary has the fifth largest urban Indigenous population in Canada and is the only large City in Canada without such a space. With over 500 places in the city devoted to cultures, gathering and spirituality, not one is specifically dedicated to Indigenous Peoples‚Äô ceremonial practices. It‚Äôs time to change that. The Indigenous Gathering Space is a response to this need and the Truth and Reconcilation Commision‚Äôs Call to Action #21 and City of Calgary‚Äôs White Goose Flying Report. name: Skipping Stone
title: Skipping Stone
main_text: Empowering trans folks. Every single day. DONATE TODAY Skipping Stone leads the way in providing affirming care to trans and gender-diverse youth, adults, and families. We offer a welcoming, positive, and judgement-free space for anyone who identities as trans, transgender, non-binary, or gender diverse, as well as those questioning, exploring or looking to affirming their gender identity or expression. We look forward and are honoured, to get the privilege of helping all our clients thrive, from kiddos as young as 6 or 7 to adults into their 60s or 70s as well as parents, partners, families and all those who love and support trans and gender diverse folks. Our unique comprehensive care model focuses on supporting people as the whole, healthy, wonderful humans they are and connecting trans and gender diverse youth, adults and families to the supports and services they need and deserve and has attracted national and international attention and acclaim. Through a client-centred, collaborative approach, we empower individuals to achieve their goals by assembling a support team tailored specifically to them. These teams might include community team members, peer mentors and coaches, social workers, mental health and health care professionals, or more. Since our inception 6 years ago, we have impacted the lives of over 10,000 individuals across Alberta.

The class is taught by Obi Egbuna Jr., a veteran African history teacher and children‚Äôs playwright with over 30 years of experience. The children learn about our history of resistance to oppression, African heroes and heroines, music from across the Pan-African world and world events from a Pan-African perspective. The focus is on Africans at home and abroad. Since this class is virtual, it is open to all children of African descent who are able to participate at 3PM MST (Calgary time). register Free Groceries program Our free groceries program provides fresh groceries to African families throughout Calgary on a monthly basis. We provide meat, dairy, produce, cleaning supplies, personal care items along with formula and diapers to families that need them. The purpose of this program is to build community by demonstrating that we can meet the needs of our people by working together. Home-cooked meals program Once a month, UAD organizers and volunteers prepare home-cooked meals and snack bags to distribute them to our houseless community members in the Calgary downtown area. Since the inception of this program in January 2022, over 1000 meals have been distributed to houseless community members. Community Learning Circles We host monthly virtual and in-person events to engage in collective learning because we recognize the importance of African people gathering to discuss the various issues that impact our community. name: We're Together Ending Poverty (WTEP)
main_text: Who We Are A diverse, grassroots group of activists who are working to educate and empower ourselves and others to take action on the root causes of poverty. We also want to create mutually supportive relationships that encompass learning and sharing. We want to transcend practices of oppression in our relationships. We welcome all who self-identify as women, trans, non-binary or Two-Spirit. Our Land Acknowledgment WTEP ‚Äì We‚Äôre Together Ending Poverty ‚Äì wishes to acknowledge the land as a living being which sustains us and all life; and to acknowledge the Indigenous peoples and their ancestors who first lived on this land. The relationship of Indigenous people to this land is the basis of their cultures and traditionally has been one of stewardship and respect. In the spirit of truth and reconciliation we recognize that Eurocentric settler cultures rested on very different beliefs that led to the expropriation of Indigenous lands and the dispossession of the Indigenous peoples living here. It is with humility that we commit to working with others to redress oppression. We acknowledge the Mohkinstsis, Blackfoot for Calgary, exists on the traditional territory of the Niitsitapi or Blackfoot Confederacy, including the Kainai, Siksika, and Piikani. It is also home to the other signatories of Treaty 7: the Tsuut‚Äôina and the Iyarhe Nations of Bearspaw, Goodstoney and Chiniki; as well as to the M√©tis Nation, Districts 5 and 6. main_text: APN Executive Director, Trevor Rueger, Stepping Down We‚Äôd like to share with our membership and supporters that our APN Executive Director Trevor Rueger is moving on to other adventures and will be leaving his position in January 2026. After 19 years of leading APN, he is excited to be opening up a new chapter in his professional life. He will stay on to ease the transition for a new Executive Director and remains one of the many incredible members of this organization. On behalf of the Board and myself, we are grateful and honoured to have worked with Trevor on the programs and services that APN offers to Alberta‚Äôs playwrights. His thoughtful approach, his kindness to all who encountered him, has been inspirational. Many of us playwrights would not be where we are without Trevor‚Äôs guidance and abilities as a dramaturge but also as a coach and mentor. I personally have benefited from his advocacy for my work and cannot begin to thank him. All these great attributes, however, were always tempered by his incredible good humour and a lot of jokes that kept me laughing. I and the Board are excited and supportive of Trevor‚Äôs next move and can‚Äôt wait to see what is in store for him next. The posting for the position is available by clicking HERE . name: Affirming Connections
title: home page - affirming connections
main_text: Affirming Connections strengthens and amplifies the voices & actions of fully inclusive faith communities and individuals. With expertise in the complex intersections of queerness and faith, we offer educational programming , advocacy, leadership support, and theological resources to meet the unique needs of the communities we serve. We support queer individuals at all stages of their journey; everyone deserves to be all parts of who they are. We engage in the public square alongside 2SLGBTQIA+ communities, allies, & organizations who advocate for spaces of true belonging that affirm the dignity and rights of all people. We offer accessible education for faith communities because inclusion is not optional - it is life-saving and essential for a thriving, diverse society. Our vision is a future free from religious discrimination, where all 2SLGBTQIA+ people and families are safe, celebrated, and valued. Find out more about what we‚Äôre up to !

By amplifying marginalized voices, fostering understanding, and building bridges of solidarity, we confront injustice and strive for a future where dignity, justice, and cultural appreciation thrive. Our Mission Our mission is to raise awareness of Palestinian history and culture, advocate against injustices, and collaborate with individuals and organizations that share our vision. We believe education and activism can drive meaningful change and create a more equitable world. name: Society of Alberta Asexuals and Aromantics
title: Society of Alberta Asexuals and Aromantics  | abacesandaros
main_text: Asexuals & aromantics are underrepresented both in popular media and the 2SLGBTQIA+ community. Words like ‚Äúgay‚Äù or ‚Äúbi‚Äù are familiar to most people, but when it comes to the ‚ÄúA‚Äù spectrum of identities, many do not recognize that these even exist. Few people have a basic understanding of what it really means to be asexual or aromantic, or that they are valid orientations which are part of the 2SLGBTQIA+ community and face societal discrimination. Thus, outreach and education are important to those who fall within the asexual and aromantic spectrums. The Society of Asexuals and Aromantics of Alberta (SAAA) was founded to allow us to be visible, to represent who we are, and to spread awareness. We provide a valuable safe space for a-specs to form community in Alberta, and pursue opportunities for education, advocacy, and public outreach. We affirm that: we exist we are not broken we are proud of who we are our experiences matter we are not alone we are relevant we are part of the 2SLGBTQIA+ community Whether you identify on the asexual or aromantic spectrums, are questioning/unlabelled, or are an ally seeking to learn, we welcome you! Every month, we host a range of events both online and in person across Alberta, many of which are open to the public. We provide online & print educational resources, and have speakers who would be happy to give a talk or workshop for your own organization. Watch WE'RE EMBRACING OUR ROOTS ANNOUNCEMENT: Who We Are: Miskanawah (meaning ‚Äúmany little paths‚Äù in Cree) is an Indigenous-led charitable organization, grounded in cultural traditions and teachings, and has operated in Calgary for over 35 years. Miskanawah is a multi-service organization, offering programs and services in the areas of family support (ranging from prevention and early intervention to intervention), youth services, clinical and cultural mental health supports, crisis support, housing support, and cultural and ceremonial supports. Learn More What We Offer: Guided by Indigenous teachings, Miskanawah offers culturally based, supportive services to people in the Calgary area as they strengthen their circles of self, family, community, and culture. All Miskanawah programs and offerings are rooted in the concept of Wahkotiwin (Cree for 'living in relationship'). By working in alignment with Wahkotiwin, Miskanawah creates a stronger sense of community and inclusion, becoming more than an agency people can access or are referred to for services. Miskanawah becomes a community stream within itself, where those who choose to engage can Miskamaso (Cree for 'discover for yourself') a Wahkotiwin journey. The intent is to develop a sense of community for families in an environment of belonging and cultural safety, where the hopes and aspirations of individuals, families and children are encouraged and supported. Learn More Building Relatives: Guided by the traditional teachings embedded within Wahkotiwin (Cree Natural Law of interconnection and kinship), our relationships and connections with those we serve are the foundation for the services we provide. The novel follows Joseph Knecht‚Äôs rise through the scholarly province of Castalia, exploring the tension between pure intellectual contemplation and the demands of lived experience. Philosophically, the novel examines the limits of abstraction , the responsibilities of the intellectual , the search for wholeness, and different stages of development . Hesse draws on Eastern mysticism, Platonic idealism, and the dichotomy between the contemplative and active life. Knecht‚Äôs journey becomes a critique of sterile intellectual perfection: understanding, he learns, must ultimately be embodied rather than isolated. Historically, Hesse wrote the novel during the rise of totalitarianism in Europe. The isolated, inward-looking world of Castalia can be read as both a refuge from and an evasion of social responsibility. main_text: Public Announcement It has come to our attention that an individual is claiming to support single mothers and has been collecting donations and sponsorships in a manner that has led some to believe they are affiliated with the Calgary Single Mothers Society. We would like to clarify that this individual is not associated with our organization in any capacity. To avoid any confusion or misrepresentation, we kindly ask all businesses and potential sponsors to verify the authenticity of any fundraising requests by contacting us directly at 403-971-4093. Please note that any official outreach from the Calgary Single Mothers Society will only be made through formal proposal letters or emails bearing our official logo and the signature of our President. We appreciate your continued support and understanding. Sincerely, President/Founder Shamaila Maqsood About About Our Organization The Calgary Single Mothers Society envisions a future where youth are empowered with the skills to build healthy relationships, single mothers embrace their journeys with strength and confidence, and families are supported to thrive and remain connected. Through comprehensive relationship education, celebration of single motherhood, promotion of healthy co-parenting, and sustained family support, we strive to foster a society where individuals are prepared for meaningful relationships, mothers are uplifted, and communities grow stronger together. Learn More Services Our Services We strive to offer comprehensive assistance that addresses the diverse needs of single mothers, helping them navigate through difficult times and build brighter futures. title: Home | The Living Room
main_text: Let's Hang Out The Living Room is a peer-led, no-pressure social group for autistic and neurodivergent adults (18+) in Calgary who want to make friends, have fun, and feel safe just being themselves. This is for those who need low supports as caregivers and parents are not present. Join Now Events Upcoming Events Bowling at Banquet Bar Mon, Dec 29 Calgary More info RSVP Virtual Pokemon Timed Tournament Sun, Jan 18 Discord Voice Channel More info RSVP Snow Tubing Fri, Jan 30 Winsport (Olympic Park) More info RSVP About Who Are We? The Living Room is a growing, inclusive social group for autistic and neurodivergent adults looking to connect through casual, low-pressure events‚Äã. This is an informal, peer-led group, founded and ran by Megan Sharp (just a mom!) and not an organization. That means no facilitators or staff ‚Äî just other adults building community together. You‚Äôre welcome here whether you‚Äôre chatty or quiet, experienced or new to social spaces, confident or unsure. name: Urban Planning Committee, Federation of Calgary Communities
title: Urban Planning Committee - Federation of Calgary Communities
main_text: Urban Planning Committee Share your voice Our Urban Planning Committee is a forum for open discussion on pre-determined planning topics. We meet every second month and include a mix of regular and rotational (topic-specific) members. Our planning team facilitates these discussions, providing a supportive and respectful platform for members to share their diverse perspectives and expertise. By exploring diverse perspectives, we gain a deeper understanding of community needs and the practical challenges of implementing planning strategies. This knowledge empowers us to effectively support community association planning committees as they navigate similar discussions. Collaborative Learning Open Dialogue Exchanging Knowledge Addressing Trends Join our Urban Planning Commitee! Positions Available Apply Now Types of Membership Regular Members (1 positions available) Have a broad interest in urban planning? Our regular members convene every two months to discuss the most recent developments in the industry. Regular committee members will go through a nomination process with the Federation of Calgary Communities Board. Rotational Members (3-5 positions available per topic) Passionate about a particular urban planning issue? Do you have specialized knowledge in a specific field? Our rotational members commit to participate in at least one topic annually. We select rotational committee members on a first-come first-served basis. *Both regular members and rotational members will need to review and sign the Urban Planning Committee‚Äôs Terms of Reference and Code of Conduct. Upcoming Discussion topics *Planning matters are evolutionary, and our discussion topics may change as City priorities evolve. The theme for 2025 is The Role of Communities. name: Art for Social Change Network
title: Art for Social Change Network | MRU
main_text: Purpose of the Hub The ASCN: Calgary Hub operates in partnership with Calgary Arts Development, Trico Changemakers Studio, and the International Centre of Art for Social Change. The primary mission of the Calgary Hub is to cultivate, promote, and nurture the field of art for social change and community-engaged arts in Calgary, harnessing its potential as a tool for driving social transformation. We connect a dynamic community of Mohk√≠nstsis (Calgary) art for social change practitioners, community leaders, non-profit organizations, art-based groups, and individuals committed to social transformation using art-based practices. We come together to share stories, resources, and initiatives and build relationships to strengthen the Art for Social Change field. Together, we inspire social innovation through the power of art. How We Came to Be In the Fall of 2021, the Calgary Hub embarked on a journey to uncover the landscape of Art for Social Change (ASC) in Mohk√≠nstsis/Calgary through an outreach and mapping project. Through this project, we wanted to find the practitioners Mohk√≠nstsis who are using arts to inspire and catalyze social change. We explored who is doing the work, how the work is done, and what conditions enable or inhibit Art for Social Change in Calgary. Over three months, we engaged with over 190 artists, art administrators, and representatives from various organizations and communities. Our findings showed that the question of resources continues to be present for most practitioners, and more interesting was the apparent need for connection within the field. More often than not, practitioners highlighted the challenges of connecting with colleagues and sharing their artistic endeavours. This has since become the Calgary Hub's first objective: connecting and engaging ASC practitioners in Mohk√≠nstsis. name: Protospace
title: Protospace ‚Äì We make space so you can make things.
main_text: Protospace is Calgary‚Äôs non-profit makerspace. We have a community wood shop , metal shop , sewing room , 3D printers , laser cutters , electronics lab , and much more . We offer classes on equipment you are unfamiliar with, and all skill levels are welcome. Membership is $55 / month for 24/7 access. We are a quirky, fun community where artists, makers and geeks come together to share our knowledge, equipment and ideas. We have no owners, shareholders, employees, or staff. Everything we do is driven by our members volunteering. We are more than just our machines. We are a place to meet new friends, to hang out, to learn new skills, discuss common interests and network. We always welcome new members, everyone from beginners to experts and everything in between. Come build something with us today!
